<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-62] i18n issue, variant not being picked up by Validator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-62</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In my i18n application using Struts 1.1-b2, I&apos;ve used the locale object (using &lt;br/&gt;
the variant) provided to pick different validations rules.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;After upgrading to 1.1-b3, using version 1.0 of commons validator, the &lt;br/&gt;
validations that used to work are now throwing null pointer exceptions (when i &lt;br/&gt;
turn off validation for the specific form in struts-config everything works)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I was reading the DTD for the 1.0 version of the Commons Validator &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/dtds/validator_1_0.dtd&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/dtds/validator_1_0.dtd&lt;/a&gt;, and noticed that the &lt;br/&gt;
formset element, no longer takes in the VARIANT as an attribute.  I was &lt;br/&gt;
wondering why that was taken out or if it is taken out, or is there a mistake &lt;br/&gt;
in the DTD?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I know 1.1b-3 still supports the locale w/ variant as all of my &lt;br/&gt;
ApplicationResources.properties files with variants are being picked up, what &lt;br/&gt;
changed in the the Validator? Please take a look.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-Jeremy&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340487">VALIDATOR-62</key>
            <summary>i18n issue, variant not being picked up by Validator</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jeremytan@scualum.com">Jeremy Tan</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 15 Jan 2003 02:27:05 +0000</created>

                            <comment id="12403439" author="turner@blackbear.com" created="Mon, 20 Jan 2003 12:59:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It was left out of the DTD by accident, but it turns out that the Validator &lt;br/&gt;
code has never actually looked at the variant field when selecting formsets, &lt;br/&gt;
something I just discovered looking through the code tonight.  It&apos;s an easy &lt;br/&gt;
enough fix, but it&apos;s in commons-validator, so it doesn&apos;t belong here anyway.  &lt;br/&gt;
I&apos;ll re-assigning it to commons and will fix and test it, then get a 1.0.2 &lt;br/&gt;
point release so that it will be fixed in Struts 1.1&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403440" author="turner@blackbear.com" created="Mon, 20 Jan 2003 14:18:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ok, fixed in commons-validator nightly build, it will take a bit of time to &lt;br/&gt;
get a new point release built and update the DTD stored on the web site.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-61] [validator] Locale validation doesn&apos;t validate all fields (improper form processing)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-61</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Say we have the following formSet definition:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;!DOCTYPE form-validation PUBLIC&lt;br/&gt;
     &quot;-//Apache Software Foundation//DTD Commons Validator Rules Configuration &lt;br/&gt;
1.1//EN&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/dtds/validator_1_1.dtd&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;form-validation&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
   &amp;lt;global&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
      &amp;lt;validator name=&quot;required&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
                 classname=&quot;org.apache.commons.validator.TestValidator&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
                 method=&quot;validateRequired&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;methodParams=&quot;java.lang.Object,org.apache.commons.validator.Field&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
                 msg=&quot;&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
   &amp;lt;/global&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
   &amp;lt;formset&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
      &amp;lt;form name=&quot;nameForm&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
         &amp;lt;field property=&quot;firstName&quot; depends=&quot;required&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
             &amp;lt;arg key=&quot;nameForm.firstname.displayname&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
         &amp;lt;/field&amp;gt;    &lt;br/&gt;
         &amp;lt;field property=&quot;lastName&quot; depends=&quot;required&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
             &amp;lt;arg key=&quot;nameForm.lastname.displayname&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
         &amp;lt;/field&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
      &amp;lt;/form&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
   &amp;lt;/formset&amp;gt;   &lt;br/&gt;
   &amp;lt;formset language=&quot;en&quot; country=&quot;US&quot; variant=&quot;TEST1&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
      &amp;lt;form name=&quot;nameForm&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
         &amp;lt;field property=&quot;middleName&quot; depends=&quot;required&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
             &amp;lt;arg key=&quot;nameForm.lastname.displayname&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
         &amp;lt;/field&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
      &amp;lt;/form&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
   &amp;lt;/formset&amp;gt;   &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;/form-validation&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You would expect that when validating with locale en_US_TEST1 middleName would &lt;br/&gt;
be mandatory, but it isn&apos;t because in ValidatorResources.processForms() while &lt;br/&gt;
adding the default fields to the current form, we are not adding the fields &lt;br/&gt;
from the form itself! &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Now there is a decision to make and that is what is the preferred order for the &lt;br/&gt;
merged form (merged because we are adding the fields from the default formset). &lt;br/&gt;
I&apos;d say to put first the default formset&apos;s fields, but I think it would be nice &lt;br/&gt;
to be able to specify its order (for javascript mainly). &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;IMO, this bug is very related to #16920 because it is a locale issue and it has &lt;br/&gt;
to do with the way forms are processed. I would propose to have a locale &lt;br/&gt;
hierarchy: If we are using the formset with locale &quot;en_US_TEST1&quot;, this formset &lt;br/&gt;
should include the fields from &quot;en_US&quot;, &quot;en&quot; and the default formSet (of course &lt;br/&gt;
iff they haven&apos;t been overriden).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve made a patch which solves this issues. All the tests are passing fine and &lt;br/&gt;
the new one I created for checking this bug also.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If this is done properly, the &quot;extends&quot; attribute from Form gains added &lt;br/&gt;
functionality. Right now, form extension is only looking in the formSet it &lt;br/&gt;
belongs which includes its forms + defaultForms. We could have a extension &lt;br/&gt;
syntax definition for this making it possible to extend &quot;en.US.formName&quot; or &lt;br/&gt;
something like this (I am not sure if this would be useful though if we make a &lt;br/&gt;
proper use of the locale hierarchy I talked about). So the ideal scenario would &lt;br/&gt;
be to have a huge default form set, small language aware formsets, smaller &lt;br/&gt;
country aware formsets and so on. I beleive the philosophy of the validator &lt;br/&gt;
should go this way (I think it was in the first place).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Tell me what you all think and I&apos;ll submit a patch if necessary.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Nacho G. Mac Dowell&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341673">VALIDATOR-61</key>
            <summary>[validator] Locale validation doesn&apos;t validate all fields (improper form processing)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-60] [validator] Disabled is Undefined in netscape 4.7</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-60</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Downloaded the struts 1.2.8 and tried the validator framework(for client and &lt;br/&gt;
server side validations).&lt;br/&gt;
It worked fine in IE6 and Netscape 7.2 but in netscape 4.7 it gives the &lt;br/&gt;
following error:&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;form.getAttributeNode is not a function&apos;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Tried changing the form.getAttributeNode to form.getAttribute, but no luck. It &lt;br/&gt;
said &apos;form.getAttribute is not a function&apos;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Can anyone throw some light on it&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Sun&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342896">VALIDATOR-60</key>
            <summary>[validator] Disabled is Undefined in netscape 4.7</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="reddy.yugandhar@gmail.com">Yugandhar</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 9 Feb 2006 05:54:19 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:06 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:06 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12411387" author="niallp" created="Thu, 9 Feb 2006 06:46:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Struts 1.2.8 ships with Commons Validator 1.1.4 - the latest version of Commons &lt;br/&gt;
Validator (1.2.0) has changed how this works...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) First it tests if the getAttributeNode method exists - if it does it uses it.&lt;br/&gt;
2) Second it tests if the getAttribute method exists - if it does it uses it.&lt;br/&gt;
3) Otherwise uses either &quot;form.id&quot; or &quot;form.name&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can download Commons Validator 1.2.0 here:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  &lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/downloads.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/downloads.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Simply replace the Commons Validator jar in your struts application to upgrade &lt;br/&gt;
to Validator 1.2.0. More details of Version 1.2.0 and upgrading are here:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  &lt;a href=&quot;http://wiki.apache.org/jakarta-commons/ValidatorVersion120&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://wiki.apache.org/jakarta-commons/ValidatorVersion120&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you could try this version out with Netscape 4.7 and let us know if &lt;br/&gt;
Validator 1.2.0 resolves this issue, thx.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411388" author="reddy.yugandhar@gmail.com" created="Fri, 10 Feb 2006 12:13:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #1)&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Struts 1.2.8 ships with Commons Validator 1.1.4 - the latest version of Commons &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Validator (1.2.0) has changed how this works...&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; 1) First it tests if the getAttributeNode method exists - if it does it uses it.&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; 2) Second it tests if the getAttribute method exists - if it does it uses it.&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; 3) Otherwise uses either &quot;form.id&quot; or &quot;form.name&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; You can download Commons Validator 1.2.0 here:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;   &lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/downloads.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/downloads.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Simply replace the Commons Validator jar in your struts application to upgrade &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; to Validator 1.2.0. More details of Version 1.2.0 and upgrading are here:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;   &lt;a href=&quot;http://wiki.apache.org/jakarta-commons/ValidatorVersion120&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://wiki.apache.org/jakarta-commons/ValidatorVersion120&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; If you could try this version out with Netscape 4.7 and let us know if &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Validator 1.2.0 resolves this issue, thx.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the reply.&lt;br/&gt;
Even after downloading the Validator 1.2.0. it still did not work with netscape4.79.&lt;br/&gt;
But this time it did not give me the previous error&lt;br/&gt;
message(&apos;form.getAttributeNode is not a function&apos;) , but did not perform client&lt;br/&gt;
side validation.&lt;br/&gt;
When I looked into it and debugged, I came to know that in&lt;br/&gt;
validateRequired(form) method of validateRequired.js&lt;br/&gt;
in one of the if statement it was checking if (field.disabled==false). But it&lt;br/&gt;
was receiving the value as &apos;undefined&apos; from the application. So that&apos;s the&lt;br/&gt;
reason it could not perform the validation and did not show the client side&lt;br/&gt;
validation error message.&lt;br/&gt;
So could you please throw some light on how to fix it.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411389" author="niallp" created="Fri, 10 Feb 2006 22:51:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have moved the disabled check into the jcv_isFieldPresent() method and it &lt;br/&gt;
should now cater for undefined:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=376673&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=376673&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Can you test this out in Netscape 4.7 please, it should be available in the &lt;br/&gt;
next nightly build:&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-59] [validator] Int validation in Java and Javascript have different semantics</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-59</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If you run the string &quot;09&quot; through the Java integer validator&lt;br/&gt;
(org.apache.commons.validator.GenericTypeValidator.formatInt), it validates&lt;br/&gt;
successfully as an integer (as the number 9, actually).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you run the same string through the Javascript integer validator&lt;br/&gt;
(org/apache/commons/validator/javascript/validateInteger.js), it signals an&lt;br/&gt;
error that the string is not a valid number.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem is that Javascript&apos;s parseInt function (used in the Javascript&lt;br/&gt;
integer validation function) does radix snooping and uses the (pretty standard)&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;0x&quot; prefix to indicate a hexidecimal and a leading &quot;0&quot; to incidate an octal&lt;br/&gt;
value. On the other hand, the Java version of the validator uses &quot;new&lt;br/&gt;
Integer(String)&quot; to create a new Integer object.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The JavaDoc for Integer.&amp;lt;init&amp;gt;(String) states:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;The string is converted to an int value in exactly the manner used by the&lt;br/&gt;
parseInt method for radix 10.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So, the Java version explicitly uses radix 10, while the Javascript version will&lt;br/&gt;
auto-detect the radix.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not sure if I care which way this goes, but these two ought to be consistent.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To &quot;fix&quot; the Javascript version, one technique would be to trim-off leading&lt;br/&gt;
zeros (not sure what to do about &quot;0xf00&quot;). To &quot;fix&quot; the Java version, we should&lt;br/&gt;
use Integer.decode(String) instead of new Integer(String).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342666">VALIDATOR-59</key>
            <summary>[validator] Int validation in Java and Javascript have different semantics</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="chris@christopherschultz.net">Christopher Schultz</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 29 Oct 2005 12:00:47 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:06 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:06 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12410724" author="niallp" created="Tue, 1 Nov 2005 13:31:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree it ought to be consistent. Its not something I&apos;ve been bitten by though &lt;br/&gt;
and IMO isn&apos;t something critical, so unless someone is prepared to submit a &lt;br/&gt;
patch I think we should leave it till later and not let it stop the Validator &lt;br/&gt;
1.2.0 release:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mail-archive.com/commons-dev%40jakarta.apache.org/msg68919.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.mail-archive.com/commons-dev%40jakarta.apache.org/msg68919.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410725" author="martinc" created="Tue, 1 Nov 2005 14:14:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Assuming that parsing as decimal is the desired behaviour (which is what I would&lt;br/&gt;
expect - how many web apps allow users to specify values in hex or octal?), the&lt;br/&gt;
fix to the JavaScript code is trivial. Instead of:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                        var iValue = parseInt(value);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;use:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                        var iValue = parseInt(value, 10);&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410726" author="niallp" created="Tue, 1 Nov 2005 14:37:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Great, if you&apos;re thinking of fixing it Martin - the validateByte.js, &lt;br/&gt;
validateIntRange.js and validateShort.js also use parseInt.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410727" author="chris@christopherschultz.net" created="Tue, 1 Nov 2005 23:19:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=16847)&lt;br/&gt;
Converts relevant calls from parseInt&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/thumbs_down.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; to parseInt(n, 10)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This takes care of the parseInt calls in validateInteger.js, validateShort.js,&lt;br/&gt;
validateByte.js, and validateIntRange.js. Note that the parseInt function is&lt;br/&gt;
called in other places, but doesn&apos;t necessarily need to be changed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410728" author="niallp" created="Wed, 2 Nov 2005 06:10:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in revision 330124 - thanks for the patch Christopher!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=330124&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=330124&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410729" author="niallp" created="Wed, 2 Nov 2005 21:29:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;My bad, I thought I had tested this, but its still doesn&apos;t work &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Theres nothing wrong with the parseInt() change but Integer, Byte and Short &lt;br/&gt;
validators also call the isAllDigits() method which checks for valid octal &lt;br/&gt;
digits (i.e. &quot;01234567&quot;) if the first digit is a zero.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have added a new isDecimalDigits() function in validatorUtilities.js and &lt;br/&gt;
changed the Integer, Byte and Short validators to use it (also the isAllDigits&lt;br/&gt;
() function has been moved into the validatorUtilities.js).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=330243&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=330243&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410730" author="chris@christopherschultz.net" created="Sat, 5 Nov 2005 04:11:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks good on my end.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-58] Null Pointer Re depends</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-58</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When you are using Validator in Struts and you leave out the depends attribute&lt;br/&gt;
on a field, you get a null pointer exception on line 502 of Validator.  There is&lt;br/&gt;
no way to tell which field is causing this.  It would be nice if we checked for&lt;br/&gt;
a null there and threw an exception providing some info about the field that was&lt;br/&gt;
causing the problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not sure if this should be more of a Struts issue or a Validator issue but&lt;br/&gt;
I&apos;m sure it&apos;s costing people a lot of time.  I just assumed that the field was&lt;br/&gt;
not dependent on any validation routines so I just removed the depends attribute.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340532">VALIDATOR-58</key>
            <summary>Null Pointer Re depends</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mlconnor@yahoo.com">Michael Connor</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 4 Feb 2003 03:32:51 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:06 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 19 Jul 2006 14:12:14 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>1</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403579" author="dan@mojavelinux.com" created="Sat, 8 Mar 2003 08:38:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is definitely a problem with Validator since it is requiring that the&lt;br/&gt;
depends attribute be included in the validator.xml file.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is a duplicate bug to 16045&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403580" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Tue, 11 Mar 2003 23:23:32 +0000"  >

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;
	&lt;ul&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;
		&lt;ul&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-57] validator 1.0.2 in Sun-WebLogic 6.1 is not working</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-57</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have a web app that uses Struts, and also validator 1.0.2 pluggin.&lt;br/&gt;
The application runs OK in the following enviroments: &lt;br/&gt;
Windows/Tomcat&lt;br/&gt;
Windows 2000/Bea WebLogic 6.1 SP2&lt;br/&gt;
But, the same application is not running in our real environment Sun 5.8/ &lt;br/&gt;
WebLogic6.1 SP3.&lt;br/&gt;
The problem is with the validator plugging. The pages that needs validation are &lt;br/&gt;
not displayed correctly. After some tests, I can say that the servlet that &lt;br/&gt;
corresponds to a page with validator is not correctly generated (in Sun/ WL 6.1 &lt;br/&gt;
SP3) and not includes the use of class &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.struts.taglib.html.JavascriptValidatorTag&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Could you please, help me to understand what is going on ? and to find a &lt;br/&gt;
solution for this?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Solaris&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Sun&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340678">VALIDATOR-57</key>
            <summary>validator 1.0.2 in Sun-WebLogic 6.1 is not working</summary>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-56] Tests for dependent validators [PATCH]</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-56</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I wrote some additional tests to capture how dependencies between validators &lt;br/&gt;
currently works.  These tests pass with the nightly build version of the code &lt;br/&gt;
prior to any changes, so should be useful regardless of whether or not the &lt;br/&gt;
proposed changes are acceptable to the community of validator users &lt;br/&gt;
(particularly struts). &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These tests were initially attached as the first patch to &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-139&quot; title=&quot;Tests for dependent validators + Refactoring&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-139&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-484&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, but I&apos;ve &lt;br/&gt;
rebuilt the patch for the current CVS head and attach it below.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340925">VALIDATOR-56</key>
            <summary>Tests for dependent validators [PATCH]</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-53] isEmail accepts Umlauts and other non-ASCII characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-53</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;According to the RFC specification, an atom of an email address is any ASCII character from 0 to &lt;br/&gt;
127. The isEmail method accepts any Unicode character (0-65535), resulting in emails with &lt;br/&gt;
Umlauts being accepted.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;isEmail(&quot;K&#246;nig@domain.com&quot;) returns true. It should &lt;br/&gt;
not.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The regular expressions should be changed to except only ASCII 0-127 atoms.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340491">VALIDATOR-53</key>
            <summary>isEmail accepts Umlauts and other non-ASCII characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="thomas.jacob@sinnerschrader.com">Thomas Jacob</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 17 Jan 2003 18:30:29 +0000</created>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-52] Validator: date validation does not allow blank input?</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-52</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Now, date validation does not allow blank input, meens format error.&lt;br/&gt;
But there are many situations that date field needs blank input, I think.&lt;br/&gt;
If one field needs date input, It should be defined like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    depends=&quot;requried,date&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340251">VALIDATOR-52</key>
            <summary>Validator: date validation does not allow blank input?</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="kagawa@sun12.tis.co.jp">Gen Kagawa</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 29 Jun 2002 14:44:13 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:05 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:05 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>Nightly Builds</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12402710" author="turner@blackbear.com" created="Sat, 20 Jul 2002 02:28:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is an issue with commons-validator in two parts.  At the moment, the &lt;br/&gt;
default validator-rules.xml defines date as having depend=&quot;required&quot;, if you &lt;br/&gt;
remove that, it should skip null dates.  Unfortunately, the Validator &lt;br/&gt;
currently can&apos;t handle returning null from a Validation, so it flags it as an &lt;br/&gt;
error.  Reassigning it to commons since it needs to be fixed in Validator &lt;br/&gt;
(acutally, this is already an open bug in Validator), rather than in the &lt;br/&gt;
framework.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402711" author="turner@blackbear.com" created="Thu, 25 Jul 2002 23:35:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=2487)&lt;br/&gt;
Fixes generic validations to check for empty strings and return true&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402712" author="turner@blackbear.com" created="Thu, 25 Jul 2002 23:41:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=2488)&lt;br/&gt;
Forgot to add myself to the author list&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-51] Date Validation passes invalid date</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-51</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The value 01/02/199a passes the date validation.  Submitted by &quot;Alan Bowsher&quot; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;ABowsher@gaic.com&amp;gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340187">VALIDATOR-51</key>
            <summary>Date Validation passes invalid date</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dwinterfeldt@apache.org">David Winterfeldt</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 22 Mar 2002 12:21:29 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:05 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:05 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>Nightly Builds</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12402561" author="turner@blackbear.com" created="Fri, 11 Oct 2002 07:47:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This, unfortuantely, is a bug in the Java DateFormat library.  If a year can &lt;br/&gt;
be interpreted as a two or three digit year, it will pass even if a four-digit &lt;br/&gt;
year was specified.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It can&apos;t be solved definitively because Locale-dependent date formatting makes &lt;br/&gt;
a simple fix beyond the scope of Validator (i.e., I&apos;m not going to rewrite the &lt;br/&gt;
entire DateFormat.parse codebase inside Validator to catch this)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I suggest that you use a regexp rule to make sure that the date is properly &lt;br/&gt;
formatted.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_10010" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:importid">
                        <customfieldname>Bugzilla Id</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>7349</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                    <customfield id="customfield_12310220" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:firstresponsedate">
                        <customfieldname>Date of First Response</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>Fri, 11 Oct 2002 07:47:22 +0000</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12314020" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary">
                        <customfieldname>Development</customfieldname>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-50] [validator] Email validator valids email with whitespace</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-50</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If the whitespace is before or after &quot;@&quot; the email is valid.&lt;br/&gt;
For example : &quot;foo @bar.com&quot; is valid but it shouldn&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
and &quot;foo@ bar.com&quot; is valid but it shouldn&apos;t too. &lt;br/&gt;
(Cf. RFC)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Solaris&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342817">VALIDATOR-50</key>
            <summary>[validator] Email validator valids email with whitespace</summary>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-49] [Validator] ValidatorResult.getActionMap() or ValidatorResult.getActions() only contain last run dependency per field</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-49</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When calling ValidatorResult#getActionMap() on a ValidatorResult Object&lt;br/&gt;
associated with a Field which depends on several ValidatorActions, only the last&lt;br/&gt;
ValidatorAction will be present in the returned Map / Iterator.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A fix for this appears to be moving the line&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;844: ValidatorResults results = new ValidatorResults(); &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;in the org.apache.commons.validator.Field class up to outside the dependencies&lt;br/&gt;
loop, putting it as:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;835: ValidatorResults results = new ValidatorResults();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;No patch submitted for this yet and no Unit Test written. Will try to do so if&lt;br/&gt;
time permits.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This bug is also reported to the Commons mailing list at &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/jakarta-commons-dev/200602.mbox/%3c43F45A7E.8080902@nascom.be%3e&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/jakarta-commons-dev/200602.mbox/%3c43F45A7E.8080902@nascom.be%3e&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342922">VALIDATOR-49</key>
            <summary>[Validator] ValidatorResult.getActionMap() or ValidatorResult.getActions() only contain last run dependency per field</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bart@nascom.be">bart vandendriessche</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-48] [validator] Syntax/logic errors in UrlValidator javadoc example</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-48</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This is in commons-validator 1.1.4, plus jakarta-oro 2.0.8 (for Perl).  Also&lt;br/&gt;
applies to cv 1.1.3, the earliest publically-available cv with UrlValidator&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The examples given in the commons UrlValidator javadoc are syntactically and&lt;br/&gt;
logically flawed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Syntactically the jd code is incorrect in that the UrlValidator is spelled&lt;br/&gt;
Urlvalidator.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Reproduce:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;According to the javadoc, the following code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  public static void main(String[] args) {&lt;br/&gt;
    String[] schemes = &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;http&quot;,&quot;https&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
    UrlValidator urlValidator = new UrlValidator(schemes);&lt;br/&gt;
    if (urlValidator.isValid(&quot;ftp&quot;)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
       System.out.println(&quot;url is valid&quot;);
    } else {
       System.out.println(&quot;url is invalid&quot;);
    }&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
    UrlValidator urlValidator2 = new UrlValidator();&lt;br/&gt;
    if (urlValidator2.isValid(&quot;ftp&quot;)) {       System.out.println(&quot;url is valid&quot;);    }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
       System.out.println(&quot;url is invalid&quot;);
    }
&lt;p&gt;  }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;should output &lt;br/&gt;
  url is invalid&lt;br/&gt;
  url is valid&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;rather produces&lt;br/&gt;
  url is invalid&lt;br/&gt;
  url is invalid&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342652">VALIDATOR-48</key>
            <summary>[validator] Syntax/logic errors in UrlValidator javadoc example</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="walter@easypeas.net">Walter Gildersleeve</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 21 Oct 2005 16:13:02 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:04 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:04 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-47] Attempt to modify FastHashMap while in fast mode through iterator.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-47</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;DESCRIPTION &lt;br/&gt;
    Validator attempts to modify FastHashMap while it&lt;br/&gt;
    is in fast mode &amp;amp; while using an iterator().&lt;br/&gt;
    Because of changes made to FastHashMap()&lt;br/&gt;
    back in Mid August this now throws a&lt;br/&gt;
    ConcurrentModificationException which is the correct behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The offending code is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Class Field&lt;br/&gt;
    public void processMessageComponents(String key, String replaceValue) {&lt;br/&gt;
       String varKey = TOKEN_START + TOKEN_VAR;&lt;br/&gt;
       // Process Messages&lt;br/&gt;
       if (key != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; !key.startsWith(varKey)) {&lt;br/&gt;
          for (Iterator i = hMsgs.keySet().iterator(); i.hasNext(); ) &lt;/p&gt;
{
             String msgKey = (String)i.next();
             String value = (String)hMsgs.get(msgKey);
            
         hMsgs.put(msgKey, ValidatorUtil.replace(value, key, replaceValue));
          }
&lt;p&gt;       }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;SOLUTION&lt;br/&gt;
  Turn off fast mode for hMsgs.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  This is the patch solution that worked for me,&lt;br/&gt;
   there may be a larger design issue that I don&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
   understand.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  &amp;#8212; Field.java    Wed Oct  9 17:36:00 2002&lt;br/&gt;
+++ .#Field.java.1.5    Wed Oct  9 17:35:36 2002&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -439,7 +439,7 @@&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;to create the dependency &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;Map&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
     public void process(Map globalConstants, Map constants) 
{
-       hMsgs.setFast(true);
+       hMsgs.setFast(false);
        hArg0.setFast(true);
        hArg1.setFast(true);
        hArg2.setFast(true);
@@ -498,6 +498,7 @@
              
           hDependencies.setFast(true);
        }
&lt;p&gt;+       hMsgs.setFast(true);&lt;br/&gt;
     }&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;     /**&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;HOW TO RECREATE&lt;br/&gt;
  Grab an nightly struts build and drop the&lt;br/&gt;
   struts-validator.war into tomcat.&lt;br/&gt;
   The error occurs when reading in the&lt;br/&gt;
    2nd validator.xml definition.&lt;br/&gt;
   This causes an update to happen.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340357">VALIDATOR-47</key>
            <summary>Attempt to modify FastHashMap while in fast mode through iterator.</summary>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-46] Email Validation doesn&apos;t allow &apos;-&apos; in address</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-46</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;My email address is not classed as valid because it has a &apos;-&apos; in the middle.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I investigated your code, which looks fine to me. The problem lay in &lt;br/&gt;
RegExp, as it was incorrectly matching against your patterns. I looked at the&lt;br/&gt;
mailing list archives, and it appears that others are having similar&lt;br/&gt;
problems with RegExp.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So, I&apos;ve replaced RegExp in your code with Apache ORO&apos;s Regular &lt;br/&gt;
Expression handler. I&apos;ve attached the files here. This has now solved my &lt;br/&gt;
problem for me. It works with Jakarta ORO v2.0.4.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;submitted by &quot;Andy Noble&quot; &amp;lt;andy.noble@data-workshop.com&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340189">VALIDATOR-46</key>
            <summary>Email Validation doesn&apos;t allow &apos;-&apos; in address</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-45] ConcurrentModificationException thrown in ValidatorResources</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-45</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In ValidatorResources processForms(), where the browser locale differs from the&lt;br/&gt;
default locale, the following code is entered:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    // Skip default FormSet&lt;br/&gt;
    if (key.equals(defaultKey)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        continue;
    }
&lt;p&gt;====&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    List formsets = (List) hFormSets.get(key);&lt;br/&gt;
    Iterator formsetsIterator = formsets.iterator();&lt;br/&gt;
    while (formsetsIterator.hasNext()) {&lt;br/&gt;
        FormSet fs = (FormSet) formsetsIterator.next();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        // Loop through Forms and copy/clone fields from default locale&lt;br/&gt;
        for (Iterator x = fs.getForms().keySet().iterator(); x.hasNext()&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; {&lt;br/&gt;
            String formKey = (String) x.next();&lt;br/&gt;
            Form form = (Form) fs.getForms().get(formKey);&lt;br/&gt;
            // Create a new Form object so the order from the default is &lt;br/&gt;
            // maintained (very noticable in the JavaScript).&lt;br/&gt;
            Form newForm = new Form();&lt;br/&gt;
            newForm.setName(form.getName());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            // Loop through the default locale form&apos;s fields&lt;br/&gt;
           // If they don&apos;t exist in the current locale&apos;s form, then clone them.&lt;br/&gt;
            Form defaultForm = get(defaultLocale, formKey);&lt;br/&gt;
             for (Iterator defaultFields = defaultForm.getFields().iterator();&lt;br/&gt;
                defaultFields.hasNext();&lt;br/&gt;
                ) {&lt;br/&gt;
                Field defaultField = (Field) defaultFields.next();&lt;br/&gt;
                String fieldKey = defaultField.getKey();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                if (form.getFieldMap().containsKey(fieldKey)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                    newForm.addField(
                        (Field) form.getFieldMap().get(fieldKey));
                }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
                    Field field =
                        getClosestLocaleField(fs, formKey, fieldKey);
                    newForm.addField((Field) field.clone());
                }
&lt;p&gt;            }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;********&amp;gt;    fs.addForm(newForm);&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;as can be seen above, the form is added to the FormSet within the iteration&lt;br/&gt;
and this causes a ConcurrentModificationException.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341126">VALIDATOR-45</key>
            <summary>ConcurrentModificationException thrown in ValidatorResources</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="5">Cannot Reproduce</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="paul_rice@lbss.com">Paul Rice</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 26 Nov 2003 23:13:55 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:04 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:04 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>Nightly Builds</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405557" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Wed, 26 Nov 2003 23:40:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Probably the easiest way to fix this is to copy the keys into a new Set to &lt;br/&gt;
iterate over.  Instead of this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;for (Iterator x = fs.getForms().keySet().iterator(); x.hasNext()&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;we would do this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Set copyKeys = new HashSet(fs.getForms().keySet());&lt;br/&gt;
for (Iterator x = copyKeys.iterator(); x.hasNext()&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This way, the Set&apos;s iterator is independent from the underlying Map that&apos;s &lt;br/&gt;
causing the exception.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405558" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Fri, 28 Nov 2003 10:09:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I am unable to reproduce this exception.  The test cases run through this code&lt;br/&gt;
just fine with Sun&apos;s 1.4.2 JDK.  What Java version are you using?  What version&lt;br/&gt;
of validator are you using?  Do the test cases pass on your build?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405559" author="rleland" created="Tue, 2 Dec 2003 02:33:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This sounds like a bug/patch I submitted on Validator&lt;br/&gt;
that James Turner applied.&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://nagoya.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=13472&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://nagoya.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=13472&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405560" author="rleland" created="Tue, 16 Dec 2003 10:32:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Paul I am pretty sure this is fixed in the 1.1.0 release and the upcoming&lt;br/&gt;
1.1.1 release. If you are using struts download a nightly build and see if this&lt;br/&gt;
still happens. I am closing this ticket, but if this happend for a nightly build&lt;br/&gt;
then please reopen.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-44] [validator] JavaScript email validation doesn&apos;t accept 4 letter TLDs (.info,.name)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-44</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The javascript part of commons-validator&apos;s email validation (checked against&lt;br/&gt;
version 1.1.3) doesn&apos;t support 4 letter TLDs (as .info or .name).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ll attach a patch for the issue&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341799">VALIDATOR-44</key>
            <summary>[validator] JavaScript email validation doesn&apos;t accept 4 letter TLDs (.info,.name)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jan@dittberner.info">Jan Dittberner</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 11 Oct 2004 22:03:44 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:04 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 19 Jul 2006 14:12:49 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>1.2.0 Release</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>2</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>

patch for 31644&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407779" author="joerg.schaible@gmx.de" created="Mon, 11 Oct 2004 22:27:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Well, .museum has 6 chars ...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407780" author="ralfhauser" created="Sat, 5 Feb 2005 18:51:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;the 4 letter TLDs appear to be fixed by commons-validator-1.1.3.jar&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;.museum&quot; still fails there.&lt;br/&gt;
As per &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-114&quot; title=&quot;[validator] Email: inexisting dashes and TLD erroneously accepted&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-114&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-1889&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, it would be better not to accept arbitrary 4-letter or longer&lt;br/&gt;
TLDs, but truly implement the IANA TLDs.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;see also &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-101&quot; title=&quot;[validator] EmailValidator allows apostrophes in domain name&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-101&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-1356&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407781" author="mrdon" created="Mon, 15 Aug 2005 04:43:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed, however, the javascript already accepted 4 character tld&apos;s anyways. &lt;br/&gt;
Thanks for patch regardless!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-43] password fields are not validated using javscript (lengths)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-43</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This is because the validation of minlength and maxlength on the javascript&lt;br/&gt;
generated dont test for password type fields , only text and textare&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340311">VALIDATOR-43</key>
            <summary>password fields are not validated using javscript (lengths)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="aranacarlospe@yahoo.es">Carlos Arana</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 10 Sep 2002 16:04:38 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:03 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:03 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.1.0 (alpha)</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12402875" author="martinc" created="Thu, 12 Sep 2002 12:31:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Any client validation of password fields constitutes a security hole. Even if &lt;br/&gt;
the intent is to check that a new password (or a changed password) conforms to &lt;br/&gt;
a minimum required length, that is valuable information to a cracker.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If a cracker wants to break into your site by &quot;guessing&quot; an account password, &lt;br/&gt;
or using a brute force search, any information that reduces the password space &lt;br/&gt;
to be searched vastly simplifies the cracker&apos;s job. For example, if you set a &lt;br/&gt;
minimum password length of 8 characters, and a cracker can determine that from &lt;br/&gt;
JavaScript code supplied to the client, the cracker now knows that s/he doesn&apos;t &lt;br/&gt;
have to waste time searching the space of fewer than 8 characters for a valid &lt;br/&gt;
password. That means that s/he can now focus more time and energy on passwords &lt;br/&gt;
that are likely to be valid, thus increasing the risk that your site will be &lt;br/&gt;
cracked.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402876" author="martinc" created="Mon, 16 Sep 2002 22:47:27 +0000"  >&lt;ul&gt;

                            <comment id="12402884" author="galwar@nvisia.com" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 03:45:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Martin,&lt;br/&gt;
  While I understand your concern on revealing field length validation &lt;br/&gt;
requirements on password fields on the client, I disagree with the decision to &lt;br/&gt;
have the Struts Validator skip this validation altogether on the client for the &lt;br/&gt;
following reasons:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) The server side validation validates lengths on password fields and &lt;br/&gt;
generates errors (which would most likely reveal the length requirements). &lt;br/&gt;
Having the client side alone skip it is not consistent behavior (client side &lt;br/&gt;
validation is no longer an accurate duplication of server side requirements). A &lt;br/&gt;
hacker has to post only once with empty password fields to find out the length &lt;br/&gt;
requirements.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) A simple View Source of the rendered page lists all the server side &lt;br/&gt;
requirements for password field lengths (look at the maxlength and minlength &lt;br/&gt;
JavaScript functions). In other words, even though the JavaScript does not &lt;br/&gt;
perform the length validation on the client side, the page source reveals all &lt;br/&gt;
the requirements anyway. Hence, nothing is gained by not performing the client &lt;br/&gt;
side checks. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3) Many websites list the length requirements for user ID and password on the &lt;br/&gt;
page itself for the benefit of the users (in addition to other requirements &lt;br/&gt;
such as certain characters are not allowed etc). I believe that this is a &lt;br/&gt;
legitimate use (how else do you tell users what the field length should be and &lt;br/&gt;
what the unique requirements are?). The Struts Validator pre-empts this &lt;br/&gt;
approach.   &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think the decision not to enforce password lengths on the client should be &lt;br/&gt;
left to the development team. Struts should not unilaterally make this decision &lt;br/&gt;
for them but should facilitate this approach, if possible. A good example of &lt;br/&gt;
taking this approach lies in the html:password tag, which contains a redisplay &lt;br/&gt;
attribute. If a development team decides that passwords should not be sent back &lt;br/&gt;
to the browser in clear text (on validation errors), then they can set this &lt;br/&gt;
attribute to false. Otherwise, they can leave it at true. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It would be better IMHO to have a similar functionality in the Struts &lt;br/&gt;
Validator &#226;&#128;&amp;ldquo; provide a way to do client side length checks on the password &lt;br/&gt;
fields (default) and a way to turn it off. If the latter approach is not &lt;br/&gt;
possible, I would recommend turning &quot;on&quot; the client side length checks for &lt;br/&gt;
password fields by default. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Giri&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402885" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 03:50:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s nothing stopping you from changing the javascript in the &lt;br/&gt;
validator-rules.xml file to check password length.  Struts considers it a poor &lt;br/&gt;
practice to reveal the details of password checking to the client so it&apos;s not &lt;br/&gt;
enabled out of the box.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402886" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 03:50:52 +0000"  >&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;
	&lt;ul&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;
		&lt;ul&gt;
			&lt;li&gt;*** Bug 23633 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***&lt;/li&gt;
		&lt;/ul&gt;
		&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;/ul&gt;
	&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12402887" author="galwar@nvisia.com" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 04:46:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If one modifies the JavaScript in validator-rules.xml, then what happens if in &lt;br/&gt;
Struts 1.2 or a future release, the JavaScript is modified by the default &lt;br/&gt;
Struts implementation? One is left with the job of merging their changes into &lt;br/&gt;
the new Struts implementation. I don&apos;t think that this is an approach you want &lt;br/&gt;
developers to take.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You have also not answered one of my main concerns. Struts &lt;b&gt;is&lt;/b&gt; currently &lt;br/&gt;
revealing the password length requirements (do a &quot;View Source&quot; and see for &lt;br/&gt;
yourself - all the error message text which would be displayed on the server &lt;br/&gt;
side is in the JavaScript that is sent to the browser). If you think it is a &lt;br/&gt;
poor practice, then the Struts Validator should be modified so that it does not &lt;br/&gt;
reveal the error message text for password fields. One could also argue that &lt;br/&gt;
the html:password tag should not be sending the password back in clear text by &lt;br/&gt;
default. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As it stands now, I do not see why allowing client side validation on password &lt;br/&gt;
fields would be any more damaging than revealing the field length requirements &lt;br/&gt;
in the page source and on the server side on validation errors (which occurs in &lt;br/&gt;
the 1.1 release). &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402888" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 04:54:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The validator only displays the text that you tell it to.  If you define your &lt;br/&gt;
error message to include the minimum number of characters, then it will display &lt;br/&gt;
that.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Struts validator will not be changed to reveal the details of password field &lt;br/&gt;
validation on the client side.  If you want that behavior, you&apos;ll need to modify &lt;br/&gt;
the javascript.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402889" author="rleland" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 10:03:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Please read these comments carefully, and those of  Giri Alwar.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Currently, the max length is present in the html page if the field is&lt;br/&gt;
marked a password field. &lt;br/&gt;
So 1 of 2 things needs to happen.&lt;br/&gt;
1) The javascript tag needs to be modified not to generate javascript&lt;br/&gt;
the includes the min field length for pasword fields.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) The password field needs to be checked.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Having the client side and server side behave differently,&lt;br/&gt;
is kind of ugly. However, since the current default is not to check&lt;br/&gt;
we normally wouldn&apos;t change the default from what Struts 1.1 release&lt;br/&gt;
does. We can introduce a &apos;check&apos; attribute&lt;br/&gt;
for those people who do want to do this. This then adds a special&lt;br/&gt;
attribute to the password tag that is not present in other tags.&lt;br/&gt;
This is also ugly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Option 1 Would require the creation of either a:&lt;br/&gt;
 &apos;password&apos; rule, &apos;server-only&apos; rule, or adding an attribute to &lt;br/&gt;
 the validator-rule.xml file to say never check on client side&lt;br/&gt;
 &apos;and&apos; don&apos;t generate javascript that would disclose any information&lt;br/&gt;
 about this field. However if the value is still checked on the server&lt;br/&gt;
 side then the validator will return a error message telling the hacker&lt;br/&gt;
what the length is anyway.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So option 1 is NOT an option.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If users don&apos;t want the max/min length of a fields revealed then developers&lt;br/&gt;
should not use the validator to inforce min/max. Instead they should use&lt;br/&gt;
the business logic to return some cryptic message.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Hence the behavior must change to be consistent.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402890" author="rleland" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 10:05:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Lick over to commons&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402891" author="rleland" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 10:06:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is fixed in the Nightly build of Commons Validator.&lt;br/&gt;
October 7 2003&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402892" author="rleland" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 10:38:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In thinking about this Option 1 and option 2&lt;br/&gt;
they are not exclusive, and can co exist.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Currently Struts 1.1 users -&lt;del&gt;are&lt;/del&gt;- revealing their&lt;br/&gt;
min/max lengths for all fields types including&lt;br/&gt;
passwords to hackers. So a new bug report might need to be&lt;br/&gt;
filed to fix this. Again this fix would probably require&lt;br/&gt;
modifying the DTD for the validator to say drop the server&lt;br/&gt;
side checks, for all or some of the rules, and MOST importantly&lt;br/&gt;
don&apos;t generate the accompaning javascript.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;A second alternative would be to define a new rule, to prevent&lt;br/&gt;
from modifying the DTD, which is a hack.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Either approach would solve needs of both camps, since neither needs&lt;br/&gt;
were are being met by Struts 1.1.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, I believe the best option is for users not to use the&lt;br/&gt;
min/max length rules for passwords to start with and keep that&lt;br/&gt;
logic in the Business logic.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This would keep the javascript tag from becomming overly complicated.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402893" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 21:08:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Reopening as this isn&apos;t fixed yet.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12402894" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Oct 2003 21:09:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The issues brought up at the end of this report are now being tracked under bug# &lt;br/&gt;
23652.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-40] Digester unable to resolve external DTD</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-40</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Yesterday morning the apache site was unavailable. Because of this I discovered &lt;br/&gt;
that Validator was unable to parse the validations.xml because it couldn&apos;t get &lt;br/&gt;
to the DTD. I discovered that, although the struts core registers it&apos;s DTDs &lt;br/&gt;
with Digester so that the ones in the jar file can be used, Validator does not.&lt;br/&gt;
I have created a patch to fix this and will attach a diff -u file in case this &lt;br/&gt;
is seen as a useful thing.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340335">VALIDATOR-40</key>
            <summary>Digester unable to resolve external DTD</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
